thread.title: What Jose Mourinho has said prior to facing Chelsea in the past - and what it says about his relationship with the Blues
thread.title_full: What Jose Mourinho has said prior to facing Chelsea in the past - and what it says about his relationship with the Blues

author: Jake Polden
title: What Jose Mourinho has said prior to facing Chelsea in the past - and what it says about his relationship with the Blues
text:
Get Chelsea FC   Could   
Jose Mourinho returns to his old stomping ground on Monday night. 
The Man United manager, who had two spells at Stamford Bridge as Chelsea boss, will be looking for revenge following his side's 4-0 humbling in the Premier League in October. 
But he will know better than anyone that the Red Devils will have to be at their best if they are going to progress to the semi-finals of the FA Cup. 
The Portuguese has a real problem in attack going into the fixture, with star man Zlatan Ibrahimovic suspended and injuries and illnesses ruling out everyone else. Jose Mourinho returns to Stamford Bridge on Monday (Photo: REUTERS) 
It is yet unclear how Mourinho's side will line-up for the quarter-final, but one thing that is certain will be the Portuguese's desire to beat his former club. 
In the above video we look back on some of the key things Mourinho has said prior to facing Chelsea as an away boss - and what it says about his relationship with the club. The Man United boss is greeted by John Terry at Chelsea (Photo: Shaun Botterill/Getty Images) 
Mourinho first came up against Chelsea three years after he was sacked, as Inter Milan manager in 2010. 
Ahead of the game he acknowledged the fact he knows the team well, but true to his mysterious form, suggested that this could in fact make his job more difficult. Mourinho celebrates with the League Cup trophy in 2015 (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
After Inter's 2-1 victory in the Champions League, he made his first return to Stamford Bridge and recorded a 1-0 win. 
Before the second leg he confidently predicted the fans would be happy to see him. The Portuguese celebrates Chelsea winning the Premier League in 2006 (Photo: Mike Hewitt/Getty) 
While after it he revealed he felt sorry for the Chelsea supporters, as well as some of their players, suggesting he still had a lot of love for his former side. 
In 2012 his Real Madrid side came close to facing the Blues in the Champions League final. Speaking about the club he admitted "they mean a lot to my life." Real Madrid players celebrate Copa del Rey glory with Mourinho in 2011 (Photo: Victor Carretero/Real Madrid) 
After his second spell in charge, and subsequent sacking, Mourinho returned to Stamford Bridge in October and again spoke about his relationship with the club. 
He said that he would never say a bad word about a former team, but, perhaps aware of managing in the same country, left personal comments out of the press conference. The then Inter Milan boss kisses the Coppa Italia in 2010 (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
This appeared to be the case after the game as well, as despite a warm reception from the Chelsea fans, Mourinho dismissed it in his post-match comments. 
In all it finally seems that after two sackings and a humbling 4-0 defeat that his love has faded, and if anything he is perhaps more motivated to get a result. poll loading Will Manchester United beat Chelsea? 1000+ VOTES SO FAR
